abstract.text: The Anthropocene is marked by twin crises: climate change and biodiversity loss. Climate 8 change has tended to dominate the headlines, reflecting, in part, the greater complexity of the 9 biodiversity crisis. Biodiversity itself is a difficult concept. Land plants dominate the global 10 biomass and terrestrial arthropods probably dominate in terms of numbers of species, but most of 11 the Tree of Life consists of single-celled eukaryotes, bacteria, and archaea. Wild plants provide a 12 huge variety of products and services to people, ranging from those that are species-specific, 13 such as food, medicine, and genetic resources, to many which are partly interchangeable, such as 14 timber and forage for domestic animals, and others which depend on the whole community, but 15 not on individual species, such as regulation of water supply and carbon sequestration. The use 16 of information from remote sensing has encouraged a simplified view of the values of nature's 17 contributions to people, but this does not match the way most people value nature. We can 18 currently estimate the proportion of species threatened by human impacts only for a few well-19 assessed groups, for which it ranges from 14% (birds) to 63% (cycads). Less than 8% of land 20 plants have been assessed, but it has been estimated that 30-44% are threatened, although there 21 are still few (0.2%) well-documented extinctions. Priorities for improving protection of 22 biodiversity include: improving the inventory, with surveys focused on geographical areas and 23 taxonomic groups which are under-collected; expanding the protected area system and its 24 representativeness; controlling overexploitation; managing invasive species; conserving 25 threatened species ex situ; restoring degraded ecosystems; and controlling climate change.

body_text.text: The preamble to the 1992 Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) affirms that 'that the 36 conservation of biological diversity is a common concern of humankind' and it would be hard to 37 find anyone who disagrees with this statement. Yet we continue to lose biodiversity, locally, 38 regionally, and globally. What is going on? Why is this still happening when apparently nobody 39 wants it to? One possible contributing factor is that the status of biodiversity as a universal 'good 40 thing' has meant that we have not had to think out clearly what exactly we mean by the term, 41 why we need it, what we ourselves lose when biodiversity declines, and-perhaps most 42 importantly-what we are prepared to do to protect it. Contrast the ongoing biodiversity crisis 43 with the climate crisis, where these questions are readily answerable-indeed, quantifiable-and 44 it is easy to see why it is climate change that tends to dominate the headlines and public 45 attention. The aim of this review, therefore, is first to clarify the meaning of the term biodiversity 46 and then to summarize the links between biodiversity and human wellbeing, with a focus on 47 plants, and to assess the major gaps in our current efforts to protect it. Numbers of species-the most widely used metric for biodiversity-are even less certain, 71 but mid-range estimates suggest that animals do much better using this metric, with recent 72 estimates for terrestrial arthropods of around 7 million species (Stork, 2018) , to which can be 73 added a million or so marine arthropods and all the other animals. Fungi are next in terms of 74 species richness, with an estimated 2.2-3.8 million species (Hawksworth and Lücking, 2017) . 75 Perhaps surprisingly, a recent estimate for prokaryotes, based on molecular sequence data, 76 suggests a global total of 'only' 0.8-1.6 million of what could be termed species, with this low 77 total reflecting the fact that most prokaryotes seem to be globally distributed (Louca et al., 2019) .

There are still no robust estimates for the single-celled eukaryotes, while land plants include 79 around 400,000 known species (Nic Lughadha et al., 2016) , with perhaps another 50,000-80 100,000 still unknown (Corlett, 2016).

All these numbers are based, more or less closely, on actual counts, but much higher 82 estimates of species richness for some groups have been obtained by less direct methods. Larsen although functional diversity-the range of things that organisms do-is difficult to compare 114 across such different groups, it is clearly low in land plants, which mostly do more or less the 115 same thing, and is exceptionally high in some protist groups.

In summary, we live on a planet that is plant-dominated in terms of biomass, bacteria-117 dominated in terms of numbers and phylogenetic diversity, and, on current data, probably 118 animal-dominated in terms of species. Whether there are fewer than 10 million or more than a trillion species, an obvious 121 question is: do we need them all? It is easy to imagine a small group of humans, using near- will often be trade-offs between provisioning services, which involve harvesting wild species, 146 and other services, including regulating, cultural, and supporting services, which depend on 147 more-or-less intact ecosystems.

The use of wild species as genetic resources does not fit well under 'provisioning', since 149 only genetic material is incorporated into the product that is eventually used or consumed. Less than 8% of land plants have been assessed, but estimates based on regional To protect biodiversity, we need to know which species are where. Around two million 248 species have been described, out of a total likely to be at least 10 million, so doing this 249 comprehensively is clearly impossible at present. The large number of species still waiting to be 250 described is known as the 'Linnean shortfall', after Carl Linnaeus, the father of modern 251 taxonomy. In practice, therefore, conservation operates on the assumption that the biodiversity 252 we know best-usually plants, birds, and mammals-can act as an indicator and 'umbrella' for 253 the protection of everything else: including most insects, nematodes, protists, archaea, and never-254 isolated bacteria. We do not know how accurate this assumption is, but it is currently the best we 255 can do. Increasing the rate of species discovery and description is therefore a key need for the on species distributions so that we can assess conservation needs and priorities. This so-called 262 'Wallacean shortfall', named after Alfred Wallace, the father of modern zoogeography, applies 263 even to the best-known groups taxonomically, although the data for birds is pretty good.

New technologies can help with both the Linnean and Wallacean shortfalls, but 'boots on the 265 ground' are also essential, and the trained people and resources for this will often be the limiting Controlling climate change is too large and complex a topic to cover here in any detail. The 461 window of opportunity for preventing global warming of 1.5 o C is closing but has not yet closed, 462 and we must rapidly reduce greenhouse emissions and maximize natural sinks (IPCC, 2018). We 463 also need to minimize the impacts of climate change on biodiversity, as we have already had 1 o C 464 of global warming, along with increasing temperature and rainfall extremes, and further warming 465 is inevitable under even the most optimistic scenarios. It may be possible to reduce the impacts 466 in the medium term by minimizing other stresses on wild species, but we also need to provide 467 connectivity across environmental gradients, so species can move to more favorable climates. 468 However, the many edaphic specialists-both plants and animals-may be unable to move 469 (Corlett and Tomlinson, 2020) and many other species will not move fast enough to track 470 favorable conditions (Corlett and Westcott, 2013). Assisted migration may be an option for some 471 of these species, but this needs a lot more research. However, many Aichi targets will certainly not be attained by the 2020 deadline and 487 achievement of the Paris targets is looking increasingly challenging. In preparation for COP26, each country is expected to update and strengthen the 523 commitments to combatting climate change made at the time of the Paris agreement in their 524 'nationally determined contributions' (NDCs). As recognized at the time, these initial 525 commitments were insufficient to meet the goals agreed in Paris in 2015, so the first revision is 526 extremely important. Each country's revision needs to set it on a path to carbon neutrality-net 527 zero emissions-by 2050, or soon after. Most of the initial NDCs focused on power generation 528 and forests, but net zero emissions will also require massive changes in transport, industry, and 529 agriculture. Non-state actors-cities, businesses, investors-must be part of this, setting targets 530 compatible with national and global goals. International aviation and shipping will have to be 531 included, for the first time.

COP15 and COP26 are not independent events, since the same countries will be 533 involved, and nature-based contributions to climate-change mitigation will feature in both. Both 534 require high ambition if they are to be successful, and both will require leadership from China, as 535 the host country in Kunming and as the largest current contributor to global greenhouse gas 536 emissions in Glasgow. One lesson we have all learned from the COVID-19 pandemic is that 537 nature does better without us. All over the world, there were unprecedented declines in air 538 pollution, while wildlife reappeared in areas from which it had been absent for decades. For a 539 few months, we could clearly see some of the damage we have done, and we will continue to do 540 unless we make drastic changes. In 2021, we have an opportunity to set the world on a new 541 course. Let us use it wisely.

FIGREF1.text: the purposes of the CBD, biodiversity is 'the variability among living organisms from 56 all sources including, inter alia, terrestrial, marine and other aquatic ecosystems and the 57 ecological complexes of which they are part; this includes diversity within species, between 58 species and of ecosystems.' In practice, when we think of biodiversity we are usually thinking of 59 the multicellular plants, animals, and fungi that we see around us. Most of the Tree of Life, 60 however, consists of single-celled eukaryotes ('protists'), and bacteria and archaea 61 ('prokaryotes') (Burki et al., 2019). 62 In terms of global biomass, land plants dominate, accounting for about 80% of the total, 63 followed by bacteria (c. 15%), with fungi, archaea, protists, and animals, in that order, making up 64 the remainder (Bar-On et al., 2018). Plants do less well in all other measures of success, 65 however. In terms of numbers of individuals, viruses dominate (c. 10 31 ), if they are considered to 66 be alive, followed by bacteria (10 30 ), archaea (10 29 ), fungi (10 27 ), protists (10 27 ), and animals 67 (10 21 -mostly nematodes) (Bar-on et al., 2018). The only published estimate for land plants is 68 for trees (3 trillion; Crowther et al., 2015). Note that many of these numbers are subject to 69 considerable uncertainties.

FIGREF3.text: 83 et al. (2017) estimate that there are six morphologically cryptic arthropod species per described 84 species, giving a baseline number of 40.8 million, and then assume that each of these arthropod 85 species supports, on average, at least one associated mite species (another 40.8 m), and then that 86 each of this new total of 81.6 million arthropods supports at least one nematode, giving a total of 87 163 million, which dwarfs estimates for all other animal taxa. They then add in associated 88 protists, fungi, and bacteria, giving a final estimate of 1-6 billion species on Earth. They exclude 89 viruses, so their final total is dominated by bacteria, with fungi, protists, and animals accounting 90 for most of the rest. This estimate, and an even higher one (c. 1 trillion species) based on scaling 91 laws (Locey and Lennon, 2016), depend on debatable assumptions and raise the obvious 92 question of how we have failed to detect this additional diversity with the array of methods now 93 available. 94 However, it would also be a mistake to assume that large numbers of species could not 95 have been overlooked. For example, the diplonemids are a group of heterotrophic marine protists 96 (in the Euglenozoa) which were unknown until 2001 and have since been shown to be diverse 97 and abundant in multiple oceanic niches, making them the most species-rich (>45,000 molecular 98 Operational Taxonomic Units (OTUs)) of currently known marine eukaryotes (Tashyreva et al., 99 2018). Indeed, whole ecosystems were overlooked until recently. The unexpected discovery of 100 the unique ecosystems associated with hydrothermal vents in 1977 transformed our ideas of 101 where and how life can thrive (Thaler and Amon, 2019), and the gradual unveiling of the deep biosphere-the microbes that exist deep below the land surface and the sea floor-continues to 103 cause surprises. Life-mostly bacteria and archaea, but also some eukaryotes-is found in 104 borehole samples to depths of < 5 km below the continents (Magnabosco et al., 2018) and the 105 total global biomass of deep subsurface microbes may exceed that of any other ecosystem except 106 forests. 107 A phylogenetic perspective on global biodiversity gives a different picture again, with the 108 animals, fungi, and land plants contributing only a couple of fairly minor branches to a eukaryote 109 tree dominated by at least eight predominantly unicellular 'supergroups' (Burki et al., 2019), and 110 the eukaryotes, in turn, probably branching within the archaea (Hug et al., 2016). Most of life's 111 evolutionary history is contained within the bacteria, and most of this diversity is found in 112 lineages known only from genomic data and lacking any isolated representative. FIGREF5.text: 122 future technology, surviving indefinitely without biodiversity-perhaps on a space station or a 123 trip to Mars. Food, fiber, and other products could be synthesized from inorganic materials, 124 although it is not clear if humans can function if stripped of their microbiome. Scaling this up to a dirty planet with 7-10 billion people, however, is not imaginable. We would at least need the 126 250 or so domesticated species that currently supply the bulk of our food and plant-based raw 127 materials (Smýkal et al., 2018). 128 Do we need wild species as well as domesticates? Wild species are most obviously of 129 value to us when they provide products for human use: so-called provisioning services. For 130 plants, these products include foods, medicines, raw materials (timber, fibers, resins etc.), and 131 energy, as well as genetic resources for plant breeding and biotechnological applications (Corlett, 132 2018). Timber and wood products are the most valuable products from wild plants in the 133 international trade, but firewood is at least as important locally. Moreover, most domesticated 134 animals feed on wild plant species. More plant species are traded regionally (bamboos, rattans, 135 some traditional medicines), and many more harvested and used locally (wild foods, traditional 136 medicines, minor raw materials etc.). 137 Some of these uses, such as firewood and forage for domesticated animals, are relatively 138 unselective, although certain species are preferred. For some other uses, such as many timber 139 products, species are usually partly interchangeable. However, use as a wild-harvested food or 140 medicine tends to be species-specific. At least a third of China's flora is used in traditional 141 medicine by one or more ethnic groups (Jaiswal et al., 2016) and at least 22% of Thailand's flora 142 (Phumthum et al., 2018). The collection of wild species also provides an important economic 143 safety net for many poor households and the consumption of wild foods contributes to health by 144 supplying micronutrients lacking in agricultural staples (Rowland et al., 2017). Note that there 145

FIGREF6.text: 150 relatives of crop plants provide an essential resource for plant breeding, allowing on-going 151 improvements in stress tolerance, pest and disease resistance, and nutritional value (Castañeda-152 Alvarez et al., 2016; Smýkal et al., 2018). Moreover, new genetic technologies are facilitating 153 the use of more distantly related species in crop improvement and highly resolved phylogenies 154 are making it easier to choose the species most likely to be useful for this. The potential uses of 155 wild species in biotechnology, genomics, and synthetic biology are impossible to predict, but this 156 potential means that species with no current species-specific use could acquire new value in the 157 future. 158 Wild plant communities also provide critical regulating services for people, including 159 regulation of water supply and quality, reduction in flood risk, protection of coastlines, 160 prevention of erosion, protection against dust and sand storms, reduction of air and water 161 pollution, and the regulation of local and global climates (Corlett, 2018). Sequestration of carbon 162 in vegetation and soils offsets some of the carbon dioxide emissions from burning fossil fuels 163 (Houghton, 2020), but vegetation also has immediate impacts on local climates through other 164 mechanisms, including changes in evapotranspiration, albedo, and surface roughness (Li et al., 165 2020). Regulating services are relatively easy to quantify, but there is usually no simple 166 relationship between plant diversity and the services provided, with monocultures of suitable 167 species serving a similar role. Where a positive relationship between diversity and an ecological 168 function has been demonstrated, or is expected on theoretical grounds, the relationship usually 169 appears to be asymptotic, so only a small proportion of the species present in diverse 170 communities is needed for maximum service provision (Slade et al., 2019). Diversity may be more important when multiple functions and services are considered together, however, since 172 different species will make different contributions to each service. Also, high plant diversity 173 favors high animal diversity, which can, in turn, increase services, such as pollination and 174 recreational bird watching, which depend on this. 175 Most of the other services provided by wild plants can be loosely grouped under 'cultural 176 services', which include a variety of non-material benefits, from recreation and tourism to 177 aesthetic and spiritual values (Corlett, 2018). Natural and semi-natural landscapes attract tourists, 178 inspire artists, and act as a source of cultural identity for the people who live in them. The 179 religious values of trees and forests are evident in their preservation as sacred sites in numerous 180 cultures across Asia and Africa (Verschuuren and Furuta, 2016). As with regulating services, 181 there is typically no simple relationship between cultural services and biodiversity. In the USA, 182 casual visitors to parks preferred to see an abundance of flowers rather a diversity of them 183 (Graves et al., 2017). However, planted monocultures provide few, if any, cultural benefits. 184 We do not know what proportion of the 400,000 known species of land plants currently 185provide species-specific benefits to people, but it is reasonable to conclude that most of them do 186 not. Many additional species are important, but potentially substitutable, sources of timber, 187 firewood, or forage. Moreover, all species contribute to primary production, nutrient cycling, and 188 the provision of habitat, food, and other requirements of animals, fungi, and other organisms.

FIGREF10.text: 196 mapped regionally and globally (Ouyang et al., 2016; Chaplin-Kramer et al., 2019). This can be 197 a very useful exercise, but to suggest that this subset of map-able services can represent nature's 198 many contributions to human welfare is misleading. Recent research has emphasized both the 199 importance of understanding the motivations and values that influence public attitudes towards 200 environmental issues, including conservation, and the evidence that people can and do attribute 201 multiple values to the same thing (Arías-Arévalo et al., 2017). Moreover, these multiple values 202 cannot be reduced to a single dimension, however convenient this might be for analysis. It is 203 sometimes suggested that unless values can be expressed in dollar terms, and thus compared with 204 the economic benefits that would flow from an environmentally damaging development, they 205 will be ignored. But if they just don't fit (e.g. spiritual values) or can only be made to fit by 206 grotesque oversimplification (e.g. aesthetic values), such a comparison is meaningless and, 207 indeed, potentially harmful. 208 A focus on monetary valuation of nature's contributions necessarily emphasizes 209 instrumental values (i.e. the values of wild species and ecosystems as means to an end). This 210 ignores both intrinsic values (the values of wild species and ecosystems as ends in themselves, 211 irrespective of their utility to humans) and relational values (the values derived from interacting 212 with nature in a responsible way), although these non-instrumental values of nature are probably 213 recognized by everyone (Arías-Arévalo et al., 2017). They cannot be monetarized or 214 commodified, and they cannot be bought, sold, or exchanged, but that does not make them any 215 less real. 216 Despite the limitations of assigning monetary values to ecosystem services, however, 217 natural capital accounting can be a useful complement to traditional financial accounting. 218 Forestry England, for example, produces annual accounts which attempt to summarize all the 219 benefits their forests provide, including carbon sequestration and recreational use whose values 220 greatly exceed those of timber production (Forestry England, 2019). Several known benefits, 221 including flood mitigation and reduction of air pollution, are not yet included in the accounts 222 because they cannot be quantified and given a monetary value, so the estimate of total value is 223 incomplete, but it is still a useful guide for management if the limitations are understood. 224 225 4. How many species are threatened? 226 Even for multicellular plants and animals, global Red List assessments are near complete 227 for only a few groups. Estimates for the proportion of threatened species in these groups are 63% 228 of cycads, 41% of amphibians, 34% of conifers, 33% of reef-building corals, 25% of mammals, 229 and 14% of birds (IUCN, 2020). Other than corals, too few invertebrates have been assessed to 230 estimate a global figure for any major group, although some groups, such as land snails (Régnier 231 et al., 2015) and freshwater bivalves (Lopes-Lima et al., 2018), have large numbers of threatened 232 species.

FIGREF11.text: 235 assessments and other sources suggest that 30-44% of assessed species are threatened (Bachman 236 et al., 2018). Threatened species are much more likely to be assessed, but an indirect approach 237 based on a large database of validated occurrence records estimated that a third of Africa's flora 238 is 'potentially or likely threatened' (Stévart et al., 2019). On the other hand, the number of well-239 documented plant extinctions is still very low: only 0.2% globally since 1750 (Humphreys et al., 240 2019) and 0.15% in the well-documented Australian flora (Silcock et al., 2019). This 241 discrepancy could reflect the difficulties of finding rare plants and/or a very long extinction lag 242 time, leading to a large extinction debt.

Birds and mammals are well-described globally, but257 there are still significant gaps for vascular plants in some parts of the world (such as Myanmar), 258 and much larger gaps for almost all invertebrate groups. Moreover, many new and existing 259 species are described from a single location and sometimes a single specimen (Deng et al., 260 2019). Such point records are little use for conservation planning, for which we need information261

FIGREF13.text: 266 step. Survey effort therefore needs to be focused on the geographical areas and taxonomic groups 267 that are underrepresented in current collections and literature. Molecular techniques can help 268 with identification and, in some situations, surveys (Ruppert et al., 2019; Leempoel et al., 2020). 269 However, arguing for legal protection of a new site because it 'ranks in the top 10% of those 270 surveyed in the diversity of molecular OTUs' will be a lot less effective than providing a list of 271 named species that will be saved! The availability of global environmental data at high resolution 272 from satellites and ground stations enables the extrapolation of sparse point records of a species 273 through modeling to predictions for its entire distribution (Jetz et al., 2019). Citizen science is 274 another increasingly important source of information for filling survey gaps for more charismatic 275 and easily identified taxa (Girardello et al., 2019; La Sorte and Somveille, 2020), in addition to 276 its important role in public education and building support for nature. 277 Finally, biodiversity data is only useful if it is accessible when and where it is needed, 278 preferably on-line. Approximate range maps are now available for > 92,500 species in the IUCN 279 Red List of Threatened Taxa, but these are comprehensive only for terrestrial vertebrates (except 280 reptiles) and a few smaller groups. GBIF (Global Biodiversity Information Facility; 281 www.gbif.org) has more than a billion occurrence records for > 1.7 million species, but data 282 quality and coverage vary greatly between groups and the quality can be difficult to check. The 283 BIEN (Botanical Information and Ecology Network) database has > 200 million plant species 284 occurrence record (Enquist et al., 2019). However, vast amounts of data held in the form of the 285 estimated 2.5-3 billion specimens in natural history collections (museums, herbaria, etc.) remains 286 undigitized and inaccessible without a physical visit to the collection (Hedrick et al., 2020). This 287 can be particularly problematic for tropical countries, where most of the relevant local 288collections may be held in museums and herbaria in Europe. A priority in these cases should be 289 the digital repatriation of these collections to their countries of origin, as 'virtual museums'.

FIGREF15.text: are the backbone of global biodiversity conservation. They function by 294 separating conservation from incompatible land uses, such as agriculture, and excluding other 295 damaging human activities, such as logging and hunting. In 2010, the Convention on Biological 296 Diversity (CBD) established an area target (Aichi target 11) of 17% of terrestrial land and inland 297 water areas protected by 2020. The terrestrial part of this target will be met on a global scale in 298 crude area terms, but Aichi target 11 also calls for the areas protected to be ecologically 299 representative, of high quality, and well-connected, and none of these will be fully achieved in 300 most countries. This target includes not only traditional protected areas, where conservation is 301 the main role, but also 'other effective area-based conservation measures' (OECMs). OECMs are 302 areas with long-term management that are effective in conservation even though this is not their 303 primary role. Examples include protected watersheds and grasslands managed for sustainable 304 grazing. OECMs considerably extend the effective area of current protection and are likely to 305 play a larger role in future if the target area is increased in 2020.

FIGREF16.text: Many of the largest, best-known, and most effective existing terrestrial protected areas were 307 established in regions that were sparsely inhabited at the time, or by colonial administrations that308 were willing to ignore the traditional rights of local people to use the area. Major expansions of 309 national protected area systems is becoming increasingly difficult because of both the decline in 310 available near-intact habitat (Tuanmu and Jetz, 2014) and the increasing recognition of the 311 importance of social equity in the establishment of protected areas (Zafra-Calvo et al., 2019). In 312 many areas, expansion is only possible if degraded sites-hunted, logged, subject to shifting 313 cultivation-are incorporated and then allowed to recover, or actively restored. Suggested global 314 protected area targets of 30% by 2030 and 50% by 2050 (Baillie and Zhang, 2018), will be 315 attainable only if the concept of protected areas is considerably broadened, as implied in the 316 CBD's concept of 'other effective area-based conservation measures' (OECMs). At least a 317 billion people live in areas that would be protected if the 'half Earth' idea was applied across all 318 ecoregions (Schleicher et al., 2019).

FIGREF17.text: the origin of agriculture, people depended entirely on wild natural resources for 322 survival. This was only possible with low population densities, however, and even then resulted 323 in the global elimination of most of the exploitation-sensitive megafauna (Haynes, 2018). The 324 increased densities resulting from agriculture and urbanization, and the associated trade, have 325 subsequently resulted in the serial overexploitation and local extirpation of many animal and 326 plant species, and these pressures are still increasing in many parts of the world. Hunting, 327 logging, firewood collection, and the grazing of livestock are the most widespread impacts, but 328 numerous other species are exploited-and often overexploited-locally, for food, medicine, 329 pets, ornaments, and assorted raw materials (Corlett, 2018). In theory, most of these species 330 could be exploited sustainably, but in practice outright bans are usually more easily enforced.331Controls on international trade through the Convention on International Trade in Endangered332Species of Wild Flora and Fauna (CITES) have been effective in some cases, but for many 333 species the domestic trade is larger so CITES is ineffective. Agriculture is the main driver of biodiversity loss, so it is essential that 341 this expansion in production is achieved in a way that minimizes adverse impacts. Production

FIGREF18.text: 342can be increased by some combination of cropland expansion and agricultural intensification 343(Zabel et al., 2019). Most evidence suggests that intensification of existing agriculture is less 344 harmful for biodiversity than clearing additional natural habitats, because even low-intensity 345 agriculture supports fewer species than natural areas. However, this may not be true in long-346 settled regions with a fine-scale mosaic of cultivated and semi-natural areas, and no large areas 347 of intact natural habitat. Similar arguments apply to the much more severe impacts of expanding 348 urban populations, with densification reducing urban habitat quality for wild species but sparing 349 the natural habitats that are threatened by urban sprawl. 350 Even if 'land sparing' is the best general strategy for conservation in both farmlands and 351 urban areas, as long as human populations and per capita consumption continue to increase, this 352 does not mean that attempts to make agricultural and urban environments more biodiversity 353 friendly are not worthwhile. In most of the world, protected areas are not large and representative 354 enough to protect all species, and 'land sharing', where people and wildlife coexist, will be 355 essential. This will be particularly important for species with large home ranges, such as 356 mammalian carnivores and large herbivores, and the presence of such species in human-357 dominated landscapes creates a potential for conflicts when crops are damaged (e.g. by large 358 herbivores, primates), and livestock and people threatened (e.g. by lions, elephants) (Crespin and 359 Simonetti, 2019).

When an alien species is established in the wild outside its 374 native change it is rarely possible to eliminate it, so control efforts must focus on preventing 375 introduction and establishment. If a species is already established, then some form of ecological 376 triage becomes necessary, with priority given to managing the species which are most harmful.377New ideas, new laws, and new technologies will help in specific cases, but the invasive species 378 problem can only get worse and currently looks to be one of the least tractable of conservation 379 issues.380 5.7 Conserve threatened species ex situ.381 Conservation ex situ (i.e. in captivity) is never the first choice, but it is necessary for species 382 and genetically unique populations which are threatened in situ (i.e. in their natural habitat), and 383 desirable, as back-up, for all species and populations which may be threatened in the future. 384 Current efforts with wild plant species are insufficient and, despite some progress, we are still a 385 long way from achieving the 2020 GSPC (Global Strategy for Plant Conservation) target of 75% 386 of threatened plant species conserved ex situ (Sharrock et al., 2018). Conventional seed banks, in 387 which plant species with desiccation tolerant (orthodox) seeds are dried and stored at -20 o C, have 388 been the backbone of ex situ plant conservation for some time, but their limitations have become 389 increasingly clear in recent years. Not only do an estimated 8% of all plant species, mostly in the 390 humid tropics, have desiccation intolerant (recalcitrant) seeds that die when dried and frozen, but 391 many crop and wild species have seeds with relatively short (i.e. decades, not centuries) life-392 spans in standard storage conditions (Colville and Pritchard, 2019). Cryopreservation, usually in 393 liquid nitrogen, is an alternative, both to extend the lives of short-lived orthodox seeds and to 394 enable the long-term ex situ storage of embryo axes, buds, shoot tips, pollen, and other tissues of 395 species with recalcitrant seeds (Pence et al., 2020). These technologies could and should be used 396 more widely for threatened plant species. 397 Cryopreservation and the supporting technologies are more expensive than traditional seed 398 banks, but much cheaper than maintaining plants in cultivation. The small sizes of the genetic 399 individuals protected in seed banks and cryopreservation facilities, and the low maintenance 400 costs, mean that it is practical to preserve many individuals from each population, and multiple 401 populations separately, and thus retain a large proportion of the wild genetic diversity. Living 402 collections of growing plants, in contrast, tend to be small, particularly for trees. There is a rather 403 similar situation with animals, although the technologies are more complex, and the current 404 coverage of threatened species is much poorer than with plants. Cryopreservation of sperm, eggs, 405 and embryos is widely used with domesticated animals, but is much less common with wild 406 species, although a number of 'frozen zoos' exist currently (Charlton et al., 2018). Traditional 407 'captive breeding' has been important largely for charismatic vertebrates, because it is extremely 408 expensive and requires international collaboration between zoos and other facilities. As with 409 living collections in botanical gardens, the limited population sizes in zoos mean that careful 410 management is required to minimize inbreeding and genetic drift.

A focus on the number of species protected may not 414 provide adequate protection for functional and phylogenetic diversity if spatial patterns of 415 species, functional, and phylogenetic diversity do not coincide. Current indices of functional 416 diversity are based on measurements of the 'functional traits' of species in the community-417 measurable aspects of an organism that can be linked with its ecological role or fitness-and 418 their application in conservation is based on the assumption that species which do not add to the 419 functional diversity of a community are redundant, and thus deserve a lower conservation 420 priority. While this may make sense when the focus is on the loss of particular function, such as 421 pollination or seed dispersal, a general application of functional diversity in conservation would 422 require that the measured traits are adequate proxies for all ecological functions of a species, 423 which is clearly not true. Phylogeny, in contrast, predicts both known and unknown features of 424 organisms which, in turn, correlate with multiple values of biodiversity (Owen et al., 2019). 425 Phylogenetic distinctiveness-the amount of unique evolutionary history-has therefore become 426 a widely accepted criterion for prioritizing conservation effort. The loss of a phylogenetically 427 isolated species represents the loss of an entire branch of the tree of life. The EDGE 428 (Evolutionarily Distinct and Globally Endangered) program of the Zoological Society of London 429 prioritizes species based on the amount of unique evolutionary history eac h onerepresents 430 (Gumbs et al. 2018). This is then combined with a global endangerment score derived from the 431 IUCN Red Lists to give an EDGE score for each species. EDGE scores have proved particularly 432 useful for identifying and prioritizing little-known species which had previously been 433 overlooked, but the wider application of this approach is currently limited by the need for a 434 robust species-level phylogeny and a near-complete global Red List assessment. 435 5.9 Restore degraded ecosystems 436 Small-scale ecological restoration projects-typically a few hectares or less-have been 437 carried out in many different ecosystems worldwide for several decades with varying degrees of 438 success. Restoration projects can provide additional habitat for threatened species while restoring 439 ecosystem services, including carbon sequestration. Recently, however, there have been calls for 440 a huge expansion in ecological restoration, encompassing millions of square kilometers, in order 441 to meet the needs of both biodiversity conservation and climate change mitigation. The CBD's 442 Aichi target 15 called for the 'restoration of at least 15% of degraded ecosystems' by 2020 and a 443 recent study estimated that at least 1.9 million km 2 of land in 114 countries will need to be 444 restored to meet the area component of Aichi target 11 (Mappin et al., 2019). A global forest 445 restoration effort, the Bonn Challenge, called for 1.5 million km 2 of land to be committed to 446 restoration by 2020 and 3.5 million km 2 by 2030. Most countries also include huge reforestation 447 commitments in their 'nationally determined contributions' (NDCs) to meeting the climate 448 change mitigation targets of the Paris agreement. It is not just the vast areas proposed that are 449 challenging, but also the range of ecosystems involved and the potential for trade-offs between 450 the twin motivations of carbon and biodiversity (considered below).451 5.10 Control pollution 452Even the best fences do not keep out air and water pollution from protected areas. Ozone, 453 sulfur dioxide, and particulates are problems for terrestrial ecosystems in some areas, but the 454 greatest concern globally is deposition of reactive nitrogen produced from fossil fuels and455 intensive agriculture. Increases in nitrogen deposition impact plant communities through direct 456 toxicity, soil acidification, nutrient imbalances, and changes in interspecific competition (Payne 457 et al., 2017). Impacts can occur at low levels and are easily overlooked. 458 459 5.11 Stop climate change and minimize the impacts on biodiversity460

FIGREF22.text: The twin crises of the Anthropocene: biodiversity loss and climate change. 473 In May 2019, the Anthropocene Working Group of the International Commission on 474 Stratigraphy voted in favor of treating the Anthropocene as a formal stratigraphic unit, starting in 475 the mid-20 th century. This starting date coincides with the 'Great Acceleration' in population 476 growth, industrialization, globalization, and all their consequences (Steffen et al., 2015). Both 477 biodiversity loss and climate change started well before this date, but it was this post-1950 478 acceleration in the major drivers of both which produced the twin crises we face today. Climate 479 change and biodiversity loss are often treated separately, but they are interconnected in many 480 ways, including sharing multiple drivers (Seddon et al., 2019). We cannot solve one crisis 481 without addressing the other. This interdependence is recognized in the most recent reports of 482 both the IPCC (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate change) and its biodiversity equivalent 483 IPBES (Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity and Ecosystem Services) 484 (IPCC, 2018; IPBES, 2019). In both cases, there are globally agreed targets, set out in the 2010 485 Aichi targets of the CBD for biodiversity and the 2015 Paris Agreement for climate change.

The new targets for 2030 need to be clear, ambitious, inspirational, and 515 measurable. A protected area target of 30% by 2030 would be achievable in most countries, with 516 the inclusion of OECMs, but a percentage target risks directing attention away from the need for 517 effective management of high-value sites and will have to be worded very carefully (Visconti et 518 al., 2019). At the species level, the only reasonable goal is zero extinction, which is already the 519 implied or explicit target for conservation in most countries and should be the global target. The 520 development of the IUCN Red List of Ecosystems also makes an ecosystem target possible and, 521 unlike species targets, potentially possible to monitor with remote sensing (Watson et al., 2020).
